## Introduction

This chapter introduces a generalized linear regression model that can be applied on count data, which is Poisson distributed. Compared to ordinary regression models, which assumes normality and constant variance--homoskedasticity, Poisson regression which models count data which is skewed and heteroskedastic. 

### Poisson Regression Assumptions

- **Independence**: Poisson regression assumes the responses to be counts--(nonnegative integers: 0, 1, 2,...). Each response is mutually independent to each other with mean parameter $\lambda_i,i=1,...,n$. 

- **Log-linearity**: Poisson regression models the link function of the response as a linear function of the explanatory variables, i.e., $\log(\lambda_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_{i1}+\dots+\beta_p X_{ip}$ with $\lambda_i> 0$. 

- **Heteroskedasticity**: Poisson regression assumes heteoroskedastic response, i.e., the variance of the response increases along with the mean increasing; in contrast to, in ordinary regression with Gaussian noises, the variances are constant and independent to the mean of the noises. Poisson regression assumes equidispersion, i.e., the variance is the same as the expectation of the response; compared to overdispersion in negative binomial distribution where variance is greater than mean.
